title: RL32914
content: Rising procurement costs for Navy ships are a concern for Navy officials and Congress. The Congressional Budget Office estimates higher funding levels are needed for the Navy's shipbuilding plan. This has led to reduced ship procurement rates and concerns about the future size of the Navy and shipyards. Congress must decide how to address these rising costs, which could impact Navy capabilities and the shipbuilding industry. Options for addressing rising Navy ship procurement costs include increasing funding, changing funding methods, utilizing multiyear procurement, adjusting acquisition strategies, reducing overhead costs, improving yard efficiency, building ships without certain equipment, and considering construction in foreign shipyards. These decisions by Congress could impact Navy capabilities, funding requirements, and the shipbuilding industrial base. One option to reduce Navy ship procurement costs is to shift to designs with lower unit procurement costs, such as lower-cost attack submarines, aircraft carriers, and surface combatants. This report focuses on this option and discusses the potential advantages and disadvantages of making this shift. Recent legislative activity related to this issue is also reviewed. The report reviews recent legislative activity on rising Navy ship procurement costs and proposes lower-cost designs for attack submarines, aircraft carriers, and surface combatants. Options for lower-cost designs include reducing ship size to decrease procurement costs. The Navy can reduce ship procurement costs by implementing changes such as reducing ship size, shifting from nuclear to conventional propulsion, and using hulls built to commercial-ship survivability standards. These strategies can save hundreds of millions of dollars in procurement costs. The Navy is considering building ships with commercial-like hulls to reduce costs and improve production economies of scale. This strategy can be applied more widely, such as using a common hull design for multiple ship classes.
